title: China trying to portray criticism of government as racism, says report
text:
"At this moment of celebration, I am working with you to expect Australia and China establish stronger links in the coming years."

Mr Morrison's outreach efforts come amid a growing political split between the government and Labor over China policy.

Deputy Labor leader Richard Marles said the state of the bilateral relationship was "terrible" and took aim at Scott Morrison for "megaphone diplomacy" by siding with the US in the trade war and calling for China to no longer be regarded as a developing country.

But Mr Morrison labelled Mr Marles and Labor naive on managing the China relationship, deflecting criticism by pointing to positive statements from China after a meeting between Foreign Minister Marise Payne and her counterpart Wang Yi in New York last week.

Both the government and Labor have been cautious about how they characterise Beijing's influence on the 1.2 million Australians of Chinese descent. Mr Morrison parried questions over controversial Liberal MP Gladys Liu's loyalty as a "smear" against all Chinese Australians, while Mr Marles said good relations between the two countries was important to that community.

Professor Fitzgerald identified numerous examples of China's Communist Party and government officials seeking to divide the Australian public by suggesting any hint of criticism of the CCP, or its influence operations, was racist. One example was in June 2018 when the Chinese ambassador urged the government to end "bigotry" in the relationship amid debate over the passage of foreign interference laws.

He said Chinese officials, media and intellectuals echoed these claims of racism, while its champions abroad "obscure critical differences between the concepts of party, government and people to ensure that any criticism of the party or government can be dismissed as ‘anti-Chinese’ bigotry".

To maintain social cohesion, such language needs to be called out.

"The orchestration of the party’s wedging exercise is clear from the absence of alternative voices among people of goodwill in China prepared to challenge claims of racism and bigotry," the report said.

"Chinese Government claims of Australian racism aren’t widely challenged in Australia either. To date, no Australian Government representative has publicly repudiated official accusations of racism and bigotry levelled against Australia.

"The result is some Chinese-Australians, along with other

Australians, are misled into thinking criticism of China is ‘racist’, particularly when it’s tagged to historical references to racial discrimination in Australia."

Professor Fitzgerald said otherwise well-founded media reporting on the Communist Party and its influence activities could inadvertently target Chinese-Australians unless carefully managed. He cited how the word "Chinese" is vague and can have a number of distinct meanings.

"All concerns arising from confusion between improper Chinese Government interference in Australia on the one side and legitimate Chinese-Australian community organisation, publication and political

activity on the other need to be addressed and allayed," Professor Fitzgerald said.
description: A leading academic warns China's Communist government is driving a wedge in Australian communities by distorting legitimate criticism of its activities.
